Platform.Title: [E_coli_2] Affymetrix E. coli Genome 2.0 Array
Platform.Description:
Affymetrix submissions are typically submitted to GEO using the GEOarchive method described at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/projects/geo/info/geo_affy.html
The GeneChipÂ® E. coli Genome 2.0 Array contains probe sets to detect transcripts from the K12 strain of E. coli and three pathogenic strains of E. coli. Using the new E. coli Genome 2.0 Array, researchers can gain a comprehensive view of three pathogenic forms of E. coli while continuing ongoing research projects with the K12 strain.
The GeneChip E. coli Genome 2.0 Array includes approximately 10,000 probe sets for all 20,366 genes present in four strains of E. coli. Due to the high degree of similarity between the E. coli strains, whenever possible, a single probe set is tiled to represent the equivalent ortholog in all four strains. The GeneChip E. coli Genome 2.0 Array tiles probe sets over the entire open reading frame (ORF) of E. coli, includes over 700 intergenic regions, probes for various antibiotic resistance markers, and incorporates additional control and reporter genes from the previous generation E. coli array.

Column.Name: Species Scientific Name
Column.Description: The genus and species of the organism represented by the probe set.

Column.Name: Annotation Date
Column.Description: The date that the annotations for this probe array were last updated. It will generally be earlier than the date when the annotations were posted on the Affymetrix web site.

Column.Name: Sequence Type
Column.Description: Indicates whether the sequence is an Exemplar, Consensus or Control sequence. An Exemplar is a single nucleotide sequence taken directly from a public database. This sequence could be an mRNA or EST. A Consensus sequence, is a nucleotide sequence assembled by Affymetrix, based on one or more sequence taken from a public database.

Column.Name: Representative Public ID
Column.Description: The accession number of a representative sequence. Note that for consensus-based probe sets, the representative sequence is only one of several sequences (sequence sub-clusters) used to build the consensus sequence and it is not directly used to derive the probe sequences. The representative sequence is chosen during array design as a sequence that is best associated with the transcribed region being interrogated by the probe set. Refer to the "Sequence Source" field to determine the database used.

Column.Name: Sequence Source
Column.Description: The database from which the sequence used to design this probe set was taken.

Column.Name: Target Description
Column.Description: GenBank description associated with the representative public identifier. Blank for some probe sets.

Column.Name: Gene Title
Column.Description: Title of Gene represented by the probe set.

Column.Name: Gene Symbol
Column.Description: A gene symbol, when one is available (from UniGene).

Column.Name: Gene Ontology Biological Process
Column.Description: Gene Ontology Consortium Biological Process derived from LocusLink. Each annotation consists of three parts: "Accession Number // Description // Evidence". The description corresponds directly to the GO ID. The evidence can be "direct", or "extended".

Column.Name: Gene Ontology Cellular Component
Column.Description: Gene Ontology Consortium Cellular Component derived from LocusLink. Each annotation consists of three parts: "Accession Number // Description // Evidence". The description corresponds directly to the GO ID. The evidence can be "direct", or "extended".

Column.Name: Gene Ontology Molecular Function
Column.Description: Gene Ontology Consortium Molecular Function derived from LocusLink. Each annotation consists of three parts: "Accession Number // Description // Evidence". The description corresponds directly to the GO ID. The evidence can be "direct", or "extended".

Sample.Title: del27_glycerolM9_mid-log_rep1

Channel.Characteristics: deletion in the rpoC gene at base positions 3132 through 3158
Channel.Growth-Protocol: A small amount of frozen stock was inoculated into a flask of glycerol (2g/L) M9 minimal media and incubated at 30 degrees C. After the culture reached stationary phase, it was diluted 1:100 into three separate flasks containing glycerol minimal media -- again these were incubated @ 30 degrees C. These cultures were the three replicates used to extract mRNA for hybridization to the GeneChips. mRNA was extracted when the cultures reached an OD of 0.3 (mid-log phase)
Channel.Extract-Protocol: Three mL of culture was mixed with 6 mL of RNAprotect reagent (Qiagen). After sitting for 5 minutes at room temperature the tubes are centrifuged. The pellets are frozen at -80 C. mRNA is extracted from the pellets using an RNeasy kit (Qiagen) and using the recommended protocol.
Channel.Label: GeneChip DNA Labeling Reagent (Affymetrix, P/N 900542)
Channel.Label-Protocol: Approximately 10 ug of total RNA extract was used for cDNA synthesis (SuperScript II). RNA was then removed by addition of NaOH and heat. cDNA was purified using QIAquick PCR Purification kit and then fragmented using DNase I. Fragments were visualized on a 2% agarose gel to confirm most fragments were 50-200 bp. cDNA was 3'-terminal labeled using the GeneChip DNA Labeling Reagent.

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: Hybridization was performed using an Affymetrix Hybridization Oven 320. Chip washing and staining was performed using a GeneChip Fluidics Station 450.
Sample.Scan-Protocol: The microarray was scanned at 500nm pixel resolution to get an image file by the GeneChip Scanner 3000 (Affymetrix).
Sample.Description: The purpose of the experiment was to observe gene expression differences in mid-log phase growth of E. coli K-12 in glycerol M9 minimal media resulting from certain RNA polymerase (rpoC) mutations which had appeared during adaptive evolution in glycerol M9 minimal media.
Sample.Data-Processing: The twelve .cel files representing the expression measurements for triplicates of wild-type E. coli K-12 MG1655 and three related RNAP mutants were normalized together using RMAExpress and written to file using log-scale. Gene names were assigned to results by mapping the gene probe ID to annotation using the Probe Set Data provided by Affymetrix. Only probes which mapped to a gene synonym (three or four letters, such as hfq or rpoC) or a Blattner number (a "b" followed by a four-digit number, such as b1234) were considered in further analysis. There were 4070 such probes. Therefore, the VALUEs in the processed file are RMA-normalized log-scale values for the signal of probes on the GeneChip that corresponded to a gene synonym or Blattner number in the Probe Set Data file.

Sample.Scan-Protocol: The microarray was scanned at 500nm pixel resolution to get an image file by the GeneChip Scanner 3000 (Affymetrix).
Sample.Description: The purpose of the experiment was to observe gene expression differences in mid-log phase growth of E. coli K-12 in glycerol M9 minimal media resulting from certain RNA polymerase (rpoC) mutations which had appeared during adaptive evolution in glycerol M9 minimal media.
Sample.Data-Processing: The twelve .cel files representing the expression measurements for triplicates of wild-type E. coli K-12 MG1655 and three related RNAP mutants were normalized together using RMAExpress and written to file using log-scale. Gene names were assigned to results by mapping the gene probe ID to annotation using the Probe Set Data provided by Affymetrix. Only probes which mapped to a gene synonym (three or four letters, such as hfq or rpoC) or a Blattner number (a "b" followed by a four-digit number, such as b1234) were considered in further analysis. There were 4070 such probes. Therefore, the VALUEs in the processed file are RMA-normalized log-scale values for the signal of probes on the GeneChip that corresponded to a gene synonym or Blattner number in the Probe Set Data file.

Sample.Title: wild-type_glycerolM9_mid-log_rep3

Channel.Growth-Protocol: A small amount of frozen stock was inoculated into a flask of glycerol (2g/L) M9 minimal media and incubated at 30 degrees C. After the culture reached stationary phase, it was diluted 1:100 into three separate flasks containing glycerol minimal media -- again these were incubated @ 30 degrees C. These cultures were the three replicates used to extract mRNA for hybridization to the GeneChips. mRNA was extracted when the cultures reached an OD of 0.3 (mid-log phase)
Channel.Extract-Protocol: Three mL of culture was mixed with 6 mL of RNAprotect reagent (Qiagen). After sitting for 5 minutes at room temperature the tubes are centrifuged. The pellets are frozen at -80 C. mRNA is extracted from the pellets using an RNeasy kit (Qiagen) and using the recommended protocol.
Channel.Label: GeneChip DNA Labeling Reagent (Affymetrix, P/N 900542)
Channel.Label-Protocol: Approximately 10 ug of total RNA extract was used for cDNA synthesis (SuperScript II). RNA was then removed by addition of NaOH and heat. cDNA was purified using QIAquick PCR Purification kit and then fragmented using DNase I. Fragments were visualized on a 2% agarose gel to confirm most fragments were 50-200 bp. cDNA was 3'-terminal labeled using the GeneChip DNA Labeling Reagent.

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: Hybridization was performed using an Affymetrix Hybridization Oven 320. Chip washing and staining was performed using a GeneChip Fluidics Station 450.
Sample.Scan-Protocol: The microarray was scanned at 500nm pixel resolution to get an image file by the GeneChip Scanner 3000 (Affymetrix).
Sample.Description: The purpose of the experiment was to observe gene expression differences in mid-log phase growth of E. coli K-12 in glycerol M9 minimal media resulting from certain RNA polymerase (rpoC) mutations which had appeared during adaptive evolution in glycerol M9 minimal media.
Sample.Data-Processing: The twelve .cel files representing the expression measurements for triplicates of wild-type E. coli K-12 MG1655 and three related RNAP mutants were normalized together using RMAExpress and written to file using log-scale. Gene names were assigned to results by mapping the gene probe ID to annotation using the Probe Set Data provided by Affymetrix. Only probes which mapped to a gene synonym (three or four letters, such as hfq or rpoC) or a Blattner number (a "b" followed by a four-digit number, such as b1234) were considered in further analysis. There were 4070 such probes. Therefore, the VALUEs in the processed file are RMA-normalized log-scale values for the signal of probes on the GeneChip that corresponded to a gene synonym or Blattner number in the Probe Set Data file.

Series.Title: Analysis of differences in gene expression due to small adaptive mutations in RNA polymerase B' subunit (rpoC)
Series.Summary: Studies of the RNA polymerase-binding molecule ppGpp in bacteria and plants have shown that changes to the kinetics of the RNA polymerase can have dramatic biological effects in the short-term as a stress response. Here we describe the reprogramming of the kinetic parameters of the RNAP through mutations arising during laboratory adaptive evolution of Escherichia coli in minimal media. The mutations cause a 10- to 30-fold decrease in open complex stability at a ribosomal promoter and approximately a 10-fold decrease in transcriptional pausing in the his operon. The kinetic changes coincide with large scale transcriptional changes, including strong downregulation of motility, acid-resistance, fimbria, and curlin genes which are observed in site-directed mutants containing the RNA polymerase mutations as well as the evolved strains harboring the mutations. Site-directed mutants also grow 60% faster than the parent strain and convert the carbon-source 15% to 35% more efficiently to biomass. The results show that long-term adjustment of the kinetic parameters of RNA polymerase through mutation can be important for adaptation to a condition.
Series.Overall-Design: Mutations in the RNA polymerase beta prime subunit (rpoC) were discovered in E. coli following adaptation to continual logarithmic growth (OD <= 0.3) in glycerol M9 minimal media at 30 C. We used site-directed mutagenesis to make strains of E. coli isogenic to wild-type except for single adaptive rpoC mutations. We found they increase growth rate in this condition by 60%. In order to understand how the mutations affect gene expression in this condition, we extracted total mRNA from the strains, which had been growing in the adaptive evolution condition, at OD=0.3. There were three RNAP mutants and the wild-type (E. coli K-12 MG1655). Each strain had three flasks from which RNA was extracted (three biological replicates). There were no technical replicates. The mRNA was synthesized into cDNA, labeled, and hybridized to an Affymetrix E. coli 2.0 GeneChip.
